title: Which songs nowadays best resemble the Old Norse Viking music? - Quora

response.answer_text: Nobody really knows. We know more or less what instruments the Viking-era people used: six-stringed lyres, bone and wooden flutes, reed instruments possibly similar to the Russian zhalejka, and blowing horns made from wood or cow-horns. There’s a find from Hedeby that looks to be a rebec (a spoon-shaped fiddle with three strings). They may also have played bowed lyres, something like the Swedish talharpa or Finnish jouhikko; there’s one depicted in a carving on Trondheim Cathedral, although that’s a bit post-Viking as such. English manuscripts of the time depict some of these instruments. Here’s King David on lyre and his backing horn section and dancers, from the 8th century Vespasian Psalter, now in the British Museum. Even though the original King David would have played a different kind of lyre, the Anglo-Saxon artists depicted him with the kind of instrument that they were familiar with.  That’s obviously a Christian manuscript, but the pagan Norsefolk knew very similar instruments. There are fragments of lyres, for example, known from Viking-era Hedeby, Ribe, and a Swedish site called Halla Broa. This is a lyre bridge carved out of amber from Halla Broa on Gotland, now in the Swedish Historical Museum. (Source: Historiska museet) :  A lyre was probably buried with the chieftain whom Ibn Fadlan witnessed being buried on the Volga River; he called it a tunbur, but it was almost certainly this kind of lyre. It’s been possible to reconstruct this lyre from both artistic depictions and archaeological finds: here’s one, based on the remains from the great tomb at Sutton Hoo, England (https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details/collection_image_gallery.aspx?partid=1&assetid=269705001&objectid=1496825) :  This is quite playable—it’s limited to six pitches, but that’s enough for plenty of melodies, and various playing techniques (fingerpicked, plucked with a plectrum, string-blocking from behind like King David is doing) mean you can get a lot of music out of it. The problem is that we don’t have any notated music from the Viking Age. But the medieval music specialist Benjamin Bagby has tried to reconstruct it. This is of necessity an imaginative reconstruction; we can’t know what the tunes were (and some scholars are dubious as to whether the Eddic poems were sung at all). But we do know what the instruments were capable of, and Bagby takes folk-inspired musical motifs and uses them to create an accompaniment that hopefully catches the sprit of the work. His ensemble Sequentia recorded an album of Old Norse poetry from the Poetic Edda, sung or chanted to harp and fiddle. Here they are performing verses 138–145 of the poem Hávamál in Old Norse. In this part, Odin himself is telling how he sacrificed himself to himself, hanging for nine nights, to win knowledge of the runes.  Veit ek, at ek hekk vindga meiði ánætr allar níu,geiri undaðr ok gefinn Óðni,sjalfr sjalfum mér,á þeim meiði, er manngi veithvers af rótum renn. Við hleifi mik sældu né við hornigi;nýsta ek niðr,nam ek upp rúnar, æpandi nam,fell ek aftr þaðan. Fimbulljóð níu nam ek af inum frægja syniBölþorns, Bestlu föður,ok ek drykk of gat ins dýra mjaðar,ausinn Óðreri. Þá nam ek frævask ok fróðr veraok vaxa ok vel hafask,orð mér af orði orðs leitaði,verk mér af verki verks leitaði. Rúnar munt þú finna ok ráðna stafi,mjök stóra stafi,mjök stinna stafi,er fáði fimbulþulrok gerðu ginnreginok reist hroftr rögna. Óðinn með ásum, en fyr alfum Dáinn,Dvalinn ok dvergum fyrir,Ásviðr jötnum fyrir,ek reist sjalfr sumar. Veistu, hvé rísta skal? Veistu, hvé ráða skal?Veistu, hvé fáa skal? Veistu, hvé freista skal?Veistu, hvé biðja skal? Veistu, hvé blóta skal?Veistu, hvé senda skal? Veistu, hvé sóa skal? Betra er óbeðit en sé ofblótit,ey sér til gildis gjöf;betra er ósent en sé ofsóit.Svá Þundr of reist fyr þjóða rök,þar hann upp of reis,er hann aftr of kom. (A very brief commercial: If you’re curious what the above means in English, why not check out Hávamál: A New Translation?) And here’s Bagby performing lines 194 to 216 of Beowulf. (The still pictures in the video show him playing a triangular frame harp and what I think is a hurdy-gurdy, which were generally later than the Vikings. At 1:00, the picture shows him playing the older style of lyre.) This part is about how Beowulf hears news of Grendel’s ravaging of Hrothgar’s realm, chooses men to go with him, and sails from southern Sweden to Denmark.  þæt fram ham gefrægn Higelaces þegn, god mid Geatum, Grendles dæda; se wæs moncynnes mægenes strengest on þæm dæge þysses lifes, æþele ond eacen. Het him yðlidan godne gegyrwan, cwæð, he guðcyning ofer swanrade secean wolde, mærne þeoden, þa him wæs manna þearf. ðone siðfæt him snotere ceorlas lythwon logon, þeah he him leof wære; hwetton higerofne, hæl sceawedon. Hæfde se goda Geata leoda cempan gecorone þara þe he cenoste findan mihte; XVna sum sundwudu sohte; secg wisade, lagucræftig mon, landgemyrcu. Fyrst forð gewat. Flota wæs on yðum, bat under beorge. Beornas gearwe on stefn stigon; streamas wundon, sund wið sande; secgas bæron on bearm nacan beorhte frætwe, guðsearo geatolic; guman ut scufon, weras on wilsið, wudu bundenne. There are some other ensembles that play reconstructed Viking music, such as “Det Ljomar av Viking!” (It Sounds Like a Viking!”) from Norway: Vikingmusikk (web site in Norwegian only, I fear). Here they are in a photo courtesy of the Kulturhistorisk Museum, University of Oslo, with bukkehorn, lyre, and wooden flute:  The Danish band Krauka also plays Viking music, although sometimes they use modern instruments. This is a good track, but I’m pretty sure the Vikings didn’t play electric bass or flatback bouzouki. . .  Their rendition of a Faroese ballad, “Ormurinn langi” (“The Long Serpent”, the name of Olaf Tryggvason’s enormous flagship) is a bit more traditional.
